issues.description: The problem statement text consistently refers to the class to be implemented as 'Lecture' (e.g., lines 3, 6, 12, 15, 20, 31, 34, 55), while the accompanying UML diagram (line 63) labels the class as 'Course'. This creates a direct contradiction regarding the correct class name, which is a fundamental structural element. Students will be confused whether to name their class 'Lecture' or 'Course'. The template and solution repositories correctly use 'Lecture'.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in `problem_statement.md` (line 63) to correctly label the class as `Lecture` instead of `Course` to align with the textual description, template, and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement consistently refers to the main class as `Lecture`, and the template and solution repositories implement a `Lecture` class. However, the UML diagram provided in the problem statement incorrectly labels this class as `Course` instead of `Lecture`. This creates a direct contradiction for students trying to map the visual representation to the textual requirements and the code.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in `problem_statement.md` (line 63) to correctly name the class `Lecture` instead of `Course`.
